subject: Re: [Read_Alphabet] how to transliterate cure, etc.
msgSnippet: ... Right. It s just that Peter s proposal for spelling reform suggested we all use /j/ in both _cure_ and _boor_ in order to standardize spelling. (I think
messageBody:
John Cowan wrote:
>
>
> Paul Tremblay scripsit:
>
> > First, there is the issue that American sometimes use a [j] for these
> > words, and sometimes they don't. For now I assume I should just go with
> > American pronounciation, sometimes putting a /j/ in the word, and
> > sometimes not.
>
> The differences are pretty systematic. American English (but not including
> the South) excludes /j/ from /tj/, /dj/, /nj/, /lj/. My wife, who's
> from North Carolina tells me I talk like a gangster because I say /tuzdi/
> rather than /tjuzde/. (QS-SAMPA)

Right. It's just that Peter's proposal for spelling reform suggested we
all use /j/ in both _cure_ and _boor_ in order to standardize spelling.
(I think that is what he suggested.)

>
> > Second, how to I transliterate the rest of the word? In the news, they
> > have been appearing as such:
> >
> > _boor_ => /bUar/
> > _cure_ => /cjUar/
>
> I think it's unnecessary.

By "it's," I assume you mean the /a/ in the transliteration. I tend to
agree. Which just gives me more reason to encode such sounds as [Uar] as
some form of CURE in my dictionary, and deal with the exact details
later. In the same way, [skwEar] will become skw+ SQUARE. And so fourth.

Paul

PS. I must be dense on the linguistic jokes, because I didn't get the
Chomsky joke either. He talks a lot about politics, yes, but I can't
imagine he would be exactly withdrawn if asked about linguistics. Or is
the joke kind of a dig on his theories?
